awd_titl_txt: Research: Examining the Influence of Youth-led, Museum-based Engineering Experiences on Participating Youth and the Visiting Public
awd_abstract_narration:
One way to motivate young people from diverse backgrounds to pursue engineering careers is to enlist them as educators who can help the general public understand how engineers help respond to the challenges of everyday life. The New York Hall of Science, which serves a large and diverse audience, is an ideal setting for testing the promise of this strategy. Youth educators and curators of public programs at the Hall of Science will mentor two groups of high school- and early college-aged youth, who will contribute to the design and facilitation of engineering-focused events and activities for museum visitors. They will work together to develop engineering programming for the public that emphasizes the cultural and interpersonal dimensions of engineering practices. This group of young people will be recruited from the Hall of Science's more than 100 Explainers, a very diverse group of young people who work part-time at the Hall of Science and engage with visitors as they explore the museum. Researchers will track participants' experiences and document their impact on museum visitors' perceptions of engineering. The expectation is that creating and delivering these experiences for visitors will have a positive impact on the youth participants' understanding of the engineering disciplines, and on visitors' perceptions of engineering and its relationship to everyday life.

The project will use observations, interviews, journaling and the Engineering Professional Skills Assessment to explore youth experience, and visitor exit surveys and interviews to probe visitor perceptions. Both the skills assessment and visitor surveys are NSF-funded instruments. Data coding will be grounded in the engineering habits of mind defined by the National Research Council's Committee on Understanding and Improving K-12 Engineering Education in the United States (2009). The project will capture evidence regarding which habits of mind the Fellows are most frequently engaged with. The effort will also explore how interactions with peers (as colleagues), with experts (as learners, such as with Designers in Residence) and with visitors (as teachers and leaders) may be associated with different combinations of the habits of mind over the course of the project. Visitor data and assessment data will allow the project to begin to make analytic connections between participating young people's increased understanding of culturally-situated engineering challenges, and their impact on the experiences of museum visitors who engage with engineering programming at the Hall of Science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project overview: The nature of engineering has evolved, requiring more collaborative, nimble, and culturally-aware responses to the complex challenges we face today (Lichtenstein, Chen, Smith, & Maldonado, 2014; National Academy of Engineering, 2014). To establish a more diverse workforce that can bring diverse perspectives to bear on complex problems, engineering education needs to create an inviting and inclusive environment in which historically underrepresented students and children can become increasingly comfortable, vocal, and successful in the engineering fields. 

The project addressed this issue by inviting groups of young museum educators (called Explainers) to join a year-long fellowship program in which they worked together with museum professionals, engineers, and experts to help design and create engineering learning experiences for museum visitors. The goals were a) to cultivate the "development of outlooks, perspectives, ways of thinking, knowing, and doing" that are distinctive to engineering among the participating youths, and b) to better understand how the engineering fellowship contributed to the youths' emergent understanding of engineering. 

Two cohorts of high school- and college-aged museum educators from diverse backgrounds joined the fellowship program. The Fellows first learned about engineering habits of mind (National Academy of Engineering & National Research Council. 2009) with project researchers and then worked together with exhibit designers and engineers to design and facilitate engineering-focused events, programs, and activities for museum visitors. Data collected included individual interviews, assessments of their engineering skills (Engineering Professional Skill Assessment, McCormack et al., 2014), reflection papers, and artifacts created by the Fellows. Data was also gathered from other Explainers and museum staff. 

The results indicated that the Fellows gained knowledge of engineering skills such as better understanding potential impacts of engineering solutions, and developed a much more complex understanding of engineering, seeing engineering as a design process and way of thinking instead of stereotypical jobs or tasks (e.g., building robots) after participating in the program. The Fellows also made personal connections with engineering and saw how engineering can be applied beyond STEM fields and for everyone. As informal educators, the Fellows then collectively translated these connections into the engineering learning experiences they created for museum visitors. Through these collaborations, the Fellows gained professional development in teamwork, communication, and problem-solving skills. The data showed that the framework of engineering habits of mind and working on real-world problems and with both internal and external engineers contributed to the youths' emergent understanding of engineering. The data also indicated the need to support Fellows' agency, leadership, and self-efficacy through the museum's organizational effort in distributed authority and cross-departmental collaborations. Overall, the project showed that well-designed engineering fellowship experiences in informal learning environments can help diverse youths engage with engineering and develop a complex understanding of what engineering is and who it is for. 

Intellectual Merit: This project contributed to a wide-range of literature on youth development for young people from diverse and underrepresented backgrounds (National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, 2017), engineering education and assessment (McCormack et al., 2014), public engagement with informal science education (McCallie et al., 2009), and qualitative research in complex learning settings (Walther, Miller, & Sochacka, 2017). The project also generated new insights into the learning trajectories and emergent professional identities of underrepresented youth, as well as identified effective strategies for creating more inclusive engineering learning experiences for the visiting public. These research findings laid the groundwork for more robust and longitudinal inquiries in the future, investigating how these experiences may inform long-term educational pathways, persistence, and success in higher education in engineering among young museum educators. 

Broader impacts: The project established a new system in the museum in which diverse young museum educators' voices were heard and integrated into constructing education practices and experience (e.g., developing a new exhibit). This initiative can be adopted by other informal STEM learning institutions to provide access for young people from diverse backgrounds to be part of the engineering field. By inviting and supporting young educators to expand their roles and responsibilities, these organizations can support not only youths' understanding of the perspectives and practices of engineering as a discipline but also their development in soft skills and career awareness. This approach could contribute to the knowledge base for attracting and retaining underrepresented youth in the educational pipeline toward the engineering professions. In addition, by supporting these young educators and leveraging their voices, museums may gain more access to better communicate with the museum visitors and the public about engineering and engineering-related issues and challenges, such as flood management and efficient mass transit. The approach of leveraging youths' voices in engineering education may provide insights for other organizations (e.g., NGOs and city governments) that seek to engage the public with important engineering issues in our society.
